[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Open Watcom Compiler and Linker (OWCL) defines porting requirements for Open Watcom from OS/2 to Linux, ensuring ELF and PIC compatibility.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: OWCL enables OS/2 applications to migrate to Linux with ELF object file generation, shared library creation, and PIC support.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: OWCL integrates with GNU tools, including GCC and the GNU linker, for seamless ELF compilation.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: OWCL provides command-line options for ELF and PIC configurations.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: OWCL supports 32-bit x86 architectures within Linux environments.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: OWCL operates with OWL and ORL libraries for ELF handling, ensuring compatibility with GNU toolchains.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: OWCL optimizes memory for efficient ELF object file processing.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: OWCL enables stable compilation, linking, and debugging.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: OWCL is configurable for multiple Linux distributions supporting ELF.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: OWCL integrates with build automation tools such as Make and CMake.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: OWCL standardizes ELF-based compilation, supports shared libraries, and ensures PIC compliance.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: OWCL is designed for developers familiar with Open Watcom, Linux, and GNU toolchains.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: OWCL requires GNU toolchains and lacks Windows ELF generation support.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: OWCL assumes compatibility with ELF standards and Linux distributions supporting GNU toolchains.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: ABI: Defines binary interaction between programs and OS.
OMF: Legacy relocatable object code format.
[SUBSEC] 1.9 Acronyms and Abbreviations: OWCL: Open Watcom Compiler and Linker

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall generate ELF object files compatible with the GNU linker.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall support standard ELF relocation types such as R_386_GOT32 and R_386_PLT32.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall support PIC generation and shared library creation using -zpic and -elf options (REQ-EXT-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall map ELF relocation types to ORL equivalents.

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall display error messages for invalid ELF and PIC configurations.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall efficiently process 1,000 object files per batch with a response time below 5 seconds.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall log processed object files, dependencies, and traceability information (REQ-FUNC-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall adhere to 386 ABI and Linux ELF standards (REQ-INTF-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with ELF and 386 ABI specifications (REQ-DSGN-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall maintain 99.9% reliability during compilation and linking processes.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Unit and integration testing and ABI compatibility validation.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User manuals, API documentation, and ELF file generation examples.
[SEC] 5. References: ELF specifications, ABI documentation, and Open Watcom developer guidelines.
